job_title: Care Coordinator in Inglewood, CA
pros: Executive transparency, good structure, vibrant mission-centered workforce
cons: Not a lot of opportunities for growth without a Masters degree

review_title: Toxic work culture with little support
job_title: Therapist in Glendale, CA
pros: -Clients are wonderful to work with. -Work hours, benefits, and pay are decent. -Nice offices. -Beautiful city.
cons: -Very little support from leadership or supervisors. -You will be on your own besides their direction to legally protect the organization through the minimum legal/ethical. -Severe stress and burnout will be a constant factor. -Your opinions and concerns are not heard or valued. -I saw multiple scenarios of employees suffering severe emotional challenges due to the severity of situations they are put in without support. -Overall a very toxic environment. Many have spoken about their concerns directly to supervisors, leadership, and upper management without resolutions. -They create beautiful presentations and policies but don't implement it on the ground day to day. Those changes are clearly communications from outside the department as the department leadership themselves do nothing for the changes to be executed on the ground but instead continue the toxic culture. -Employees are often treated worse for expressing concerns as blame is projected unto them. -Leadership culture of retaliation if you express concerns about lack of support. -There is a real culture of inability to look within and take responsibility from leadership down, and the people who tend to stay in such culture are enablers of it, which is why you will see these kinds of reviews continue until executive management wakes up to it and step in. Many employees have reported these things but no changes ever happen besides false promises of change. -Favoritism runs rampant as some employees get away with anything and others are scapegoated. -You will likely be faced with really traumatic scenarios and left alone to deal with it if you are working with clients. -Incredible high turnover, often within a few months, due to these stresses. These cons are about the adult department as I cannot speak about the children's division.

job_title: Human Resources in Sepulveda, CA
pros: I do not have a pro to offer them
cons: Incredibly expensive benefits and the team was not really there to teach or support. I cannot believe how relieved I was once I left. Just not a culture of kindness. Micromanagement and condescending attitudes would be how I would label them

job_title: Clinical Therapist 1 in Culver City, CA
pros: There is a HUGE team aspect and everyone supports one another. This agency will pay you better than other community mental health centers.
cons: You need to be on your documentation game and be able to have good boundaries. You need a good work life management

job_title: Lead LVN/Supervisor in Inglewood, CA
pros: Best reason to work here is the underserved population that we help on a day to day basis. All teams are supportive of one another. Thay allow options for rwmote work for most positions.
cons: Although the paperwork has gotten better it is still time consuming. One must have excellent organization and time management skills.

job_title: Clinical Therapist 1 in Culver City, CA
pros: great team environment will get your hours (group sup included) can try new groups/things
cons: you're always fighting to get paid more boundaries can be inconsistent when reinforced by other team members

job_title: Care Coordinator in Inglewood, CA
pros:
-An opportunity to work with communities that are underserved
-Great exposure to the mental health field
cons:
-Low salary
-You accumulate vacation but are discouraged to take any time off.
-Burnout is serious here just as their turnover in staff.
-Lack of professionalism from management.
-Management does not take responsibility for their mistakes and often blames their staff.
-The executive team and human resources department is a joke. There's a lack of action in responding to social justice issues that directly impact clients specifically during BLM and the beginning of Covid19.
-plenty of gaslighting 
-Lack of training
-People who lack leadership and skills are often promoted due to favoritism which impacts staff and the work they do
-The saddest and most memorable issue I had with this agency is that they go about the community stating they are active advocates for suicide prevention and intervention when they are clueless about this topic. During my time there a fellow colleague committed suicide and the way they informed us was through an email that basically read something along the lines of a staff committed suicide if you need support reach out to your manager if not continue about your day. This young man was never recognized in any meetings and nor was there a space provided to process the loss. This agency is exactly what is wrong with this nation it needs a serious management clean-up.

job_title: Psychotherapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: - good work culture - able to express my needs - good time off, sick/vacation separate - sick time can be used for mental health days
cons: - productivity focused - high caseload/heavy cases - lack of transparency with policies and procedures - higher ups are disconnected from the real work

review_title: Great place to acquire training and hours for licensure
job_title: Therapist II in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Over the course of working at Didi Hirsch, I have received wonderful supervision, received trainings and certifications in various EBPs, and developed effective skills to use with clients and families. I learned how to conduct assessments, diagnose, develop treatment plans, and integrate new interventions with families. The agency also provided additional trainings outside of EBP--play therapy which has been helpful in connecting with younger children/families over telehealth and in-person sessions. Working with families and seeing the positive changes has kept me motivated over time.
-Remote/hybrid work style is also a plus.
cons:
-Burnout and vicarious trauma is quite high among therapists.
-Not enough communication between upper management and middle management, which impacts delivery of agency updates to the clinical and administrative teams. 
-Unrealistic productivity expectations. 
-Working with families with high trauma can be exhausting. Clinicians need to be able to refer parents to appropriate MHS services at times, but there is never space to accommodate new referrals to adult services.
-The agency does not provide case management support for the families outside of sessions that can be billed. Linkages to referrals to other agencies that provide case management services is not enough for our families.
-Mileage reimbursement is not enough to subsidize working in the field or at schools for in-person sessions, especially with the cost of current gasoline prices.

job_title: Therapist in Glendale, CA
pros: Colleagues, business equipment, supervisors/managers, and tech support.
cons: Poor handling of accommodations for disabled folks. Too much bureaucracy due to being DMH contracted. High case loads.

job_title: Lead Clinical Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Remote and Flexible, great coworkers
cons: Lack of Diversity in Promotion

job_title: Research Specialist in Inglewood, CA
pros: Amazing set of dedicated people trying to make a difference under very limiting conditions
cons: Inefficient workflows, lack of agency, lack of diversity, lack of communication between upper management and staff

job_title: Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A lot of opportunity to learn how to do assessments, treatments plans, and diagnosing.
cons: There’s a lot of pressure to meet productivity goal. Perhaps it depends on the supervisor you get, but mine always made sure to mention it in supervision. It got to the point where that was the only focus of supervision. I can’t control no shows or disengaged clients and when I said that they added more clients to my caseload. There was too much pressure on this to the point that it really led me to feel burnout. No matter how hard I tried it wasn’t enough.

review_title: Heartless people that only care about the bottom line
job_title: Marriage & Family Therapist, Intern in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You will accrue your practice hours necessary for licensure at a fast rate.
cons: Management only cares about billing. They overwork the interns with no care for burnout. They also "overlook" clients who are clearly malingering in order to keep them on their roster and collect money from the government and if anyone brings that up they retaliate.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great coworkers, snacks, the work itself is extremely rewarding. Pay is decent.
cons: Decent pay but no language differential, even though the preference for language noted in the job post, interview, and is used on the job. Wants to be inclusive and dynamic, trying to, buy not paying for it feels like not enough. REALLY difficult to get time off even if your vacation time has pilled up. They are not usually approved until you find coverage yourself. They help, but it's stressful knowing it would be a hassle or would have to potentially not plan for days off.

review_title: Good position for a recent grad for a year

High pressure job. A lot more paperwork than other agencies. If you are a person of color, this company's management teams are severely lacking diversity.

job_title: Clinical Social Worker in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Administrative Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Quality of work is great, you are driven to help all the clients to the best of your abilities. Great benefits. Great external view of the company but internally not so much.
cons:
They overwork you until you're burnt out. Staff is always leaving. They listen to feedback from employees but they take their sweet time on taking any action. It usually has to be brought up to their attention multiple times. 
Raises are once a year, at the end of the year. Don't count on getting a raise over a dollar, they have to share that dollar among several employees, so you'll actually get a raise of a few nickels and dimes in a whole year for all the hard work you do. 

You work the amount of work for 3 people, and you're still asked to be more efficient.

job_title: Administrative in Culver City, CA
pros: We get as much benefits as other agencies.
cons:
There are two kinds of personnel at Didi Hirsch.  The favorites and the disliked.  

The Favorites:  are the ones who can be incompetent and make mistakes but still get praised and gets appreciated.  These people are the brown-nosers who make up most of the good reviews here.

The Disliked:  are the ones who work hard and deliver results but none of it matters.  Executives and the Favorites will find something wrong .  If the CEO/Executives/Favorites decides they don't like you, that is it.  Nothing else matters.

I have seen people start work at Didi Hirsch.  They start out very friendly and excited.  2-6 months later, you see them walk around with their head down or look frustrated.

job_title: Therapist I in Inglewood, CA
pros: Free training, many different exposures, many opportunities to assess different diagnoses, great clinician feedback and hands on opportunities to be trained by DMH on EBP's. Able to finish your hours in under 2 years and can move from adult to family and children services. My director supports self-care and encourages you to take time off to avoid burn out.
cons: Pay is not competitive, however in the field you should not be working for the money only. With the abilities to write your own schedule you can easily get another job, or have work life balance.

job_title: Therapist
pros: Great team of clinicians, lots of exposure to diverse cases, freedom to set schedule, work is different every day, opportunities to do EBP trainings eventually
cons: In FSP, it was a lot of crisis management and many clients were not in a place for therapy to be effective (needed housing first), the billing demand was high due to being contracted DMH agency and little time was available to prepare for sessions.

job_title: Therapist I in Culver City, CA
pros: If you are a Therapist Intern you can get your hours quickly.
cons: The worst experience I ever had working for a non-profit, poor management from executive management, human resources, senior management, Program Directors. The culture of this Agency is to blame, blame, blame. This company spends all the money on climate surveys, hiring consults and coaches to find out what is wrong in their agency. They have done this for eight years and still cannot figure out what is wrong. Enter this agency at your own risk.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Culver City, CA
pros:
For anyone researching DDH, this interview is specifically for the Suicide Prevention Center which is honestly a separate entity from the rest of the organization.

- Crisis line counselors are some of the hardest working, most empathetic and caring people in the entire world. Yes there are some that will rub you the wrong way but when it comes to the crisis calls we always put our individual issues aside and make it about the person contemplating suicide.
- If you're a salaried employee then your schedule is mostly flexible.
- Overtime and it's pay is available for hourly employees but you're never forced into a shift if you don't want to.
- Some autonomy to pitch new ideas or make changes to the crisis line
- Pay is competitive compared to other paraprofessional mental health jobs in LA
cons:
- Anyone above the director level have management skills that are stuck in the 90's. 
- Since SPC is one of the forefront programs of Didi Hirsch, you get a lot of media/donor attention which means upper management always has a pulse on the changes that go on WHICH I GET BUT C'MON it stagnates any growth or modernization. They have no insight to what goes on in the ground level.
- There is a specific niche of staff that have been there for awhile. They have been through crappy versions of management in the past and as a result some of the senior staff are extremely jaded and don't give management a reasonable chance. Some of them are really toxic and really need to move on.
- Don't bother volunteering to do things because they don't take that into consideration when new work rears its ugly head.

job_title: Crisis Residential Counselor in Culver City, CA
pros: You are allowed plenty of hands on experience.  They offer many free trainings.  The agency has a good and respectable reputation in the Mental Health community.
cons: Lots of stress and poor financial compensation for all the constant demands.  Miserly raises, when they actually do give them.  It is expected that the staff use their own personal property, i.e. vehicle, for agency business and if you get into an accident you are fully responsible for your vehicle.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: My co-workers are incredibly caring, kind and compassionate. Everyone pulls together like a family to get things done. The culture is one of openness and growth. Management encourages people to speak up. There are opportunities for professional development.  And great benefits.
cons: Because it's a nonprofit, salaries are not what you would get in the for-profit world. But there are other perks that make up for it. We are a little understaffed so people work hard here. But managers understand.

job_title: Psychotherapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Didi Hirsch is a nonprofit DMH contracted agency and therefore I consider them to be one of the best community mental health agencies to work for in Los Angeles because they have "decent" pay.
cons: This is a nonprofit DMH contracted agency and a lot of the time it feels like they are overworking you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Culver City, CA
pros: The office is close to my house.
cons: Too much expectation for very little pay.  Was required to work outside the office and had to use my own vehicle.  No parking in some of these places.  Employees are stressed.  High turn over rate.  I have many co-workers leave due to mounting stress.  No clear direction from management.  This person who wrote that "the culture is one of openness..." must work in the management team and is part of the problem.

job_title: Therapist II in Inglewood, CA
pros: Great Learning and Working Environment, Great Team Work, Great Morales.
cons: None really.. like any company, there's going to be somethings or people you do or don't agree with. But it's life, personalities, and company standards.

job_title: Therapist I in Culver City, CA
pros: Plenty of training and opportunities to become certified in evidence based practices. Lots of direct service hours towards licensure. Good health benefits, time off, etc.
cons: Unreasonably high client service expectations, how can you meet your goals if the time spent at mandatory meetings and trainings are counted against you? Also not great money but it's nonprofit so that's how it goes.

job_title: Research Analyst in Inglewood, CA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sepulveda, CA
pros: Good educational experience for rising therapists.  Salary could be better for admin staff.
cons:
- Silo work methodology that creates friction between departments.
- Shrinking workforce and productivity could be the Achilles Heal
- Lack of unified mission and more contemporary work methods and management

job_title: Therapist in Inglewood, CA

cons: Some locations are old and tired, should be moved.

review_title: Didi Hirsch is a great place to work

cons: Like most nonprofits, we have limited resources. Everyone works hard but the work is fulfilling.

review_title: One of the best in community mental health
